title: Low Mortgage Rates Could Mean a Busy Weekend for Borrowing
text:
With mortgage rates around their lowest levels in three years, it's likely to be a big weekend for lenders — who already have their hands full.

"Refinance demand has surged due to historically low interest rates," says Alan Rosenbaum, founder and CEO of GuardHill Financial Corp., a mortgage banker and brokerage firm in New York. He was expecting an "active" couple of high-volume days, through Columbus Day on Monday.

Homeowners have been waking up to the fact that they might save money by refinancing, even if they took out their current mortgage just last year. Thirty-year fixed mortgage rates have seen a stunning decline and are down almost 1.5 percentage points from where they were at this time in 2018.

You think that's impressive? There's room for rates to fall even further, according to a new report.

A perfect time to borrow

rawmn / Shutterstock

Rates on home loans are much lower than they were last year at this time

More

The current average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage is 3.57%, down from 3.65% a week earlier, says mortgage giant Freddie Mac.

The really striking comparison is to last year at this time, when the benchmark mortgage rate was averaging nearly 5%. (To be exact, 4.9%.)

Take a look at today's best mortgage rates where you live.

Rates on 15-year mortgages — which are popular among homeowners who refi — have fallen to an average 3.05%, from 3.14% the previous week. A year ago, those rates were averaging 4.29%, Freddie Mac says.

It's an excellent time to do a cash-out refi, Rosenbaum says, "to pay off existing debt by cashing out of the equity many homeowners have built. There are many opportunities and options available."

On 5/1 adjustable-rate mortgages — which are level for five years and then can "adjust" up or down each year — the current average initial rate is 3.35%. That's down from 3.38% in early October and much lower than the 4.07% borrowers were charged a year ago.

Calculate the kind of monthly payment you might expect from the current mortgage rates.

Report: Rates should be even lower

Antonio Guillem / Shutterstock

Some customers are disappointed by today's mortgage rates.

More

Mortgage rates may be at eye-poppingly low levels, but they could be lower still, reports The Wall Street Journal.

Rates on home loans tend to track the interest on 10-year U.S. Treasury notes. Lately, those bond yields have been falling faster than mortgage rates — in fact, the spread between the two is the widest in over seven years.

description: Plus, a new report sees room for rates to fall even more.
